did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Collection of photographs on various subjects demonstrating the technological evolution of photography, with emphasis on the period of 1822 to 1885. Includes 19th- and 20th-century photographs organized in several major groups.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Collection of photographs on various subjects demonstrating the technological evolution of photography, with emphasis on the period of 1822 to 1885. Includes 19th- and 20th-century photographs organized in several major groups: Daguerre ephemera and early photographic processes, African American collection, Mathew Brady and the Civil War, Lincoln, Native Americans and the West, hand-colored photography, and cartes de visite. The collection contains daguerreotypes, salted paper photographs, ambrotypes, tintypes, albumen prints, cartes de visite, cabinet cards, stereographs, and photograph albums. Also included are lithographic prints (some hand colored), a graphite on paper portrait, wood engraving, medals, and stamp.

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: Stephan Loewentheil History of Photography Collection.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Stephan Loewentheil Photograph Collection, #8043. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: An on-line exhibit of "Dawn's Early Light" showcasing many items from this collection.
An on-line exhibit of "Lincoln's Unfinished Work" showcasing many of the Lincoln related items from this collection.

odd.head: NOTES
odd.p:
Associated book collection cataloged separately.
See the "Cataloged Separately" list at the end of this guide for a list of the CDV albums which have also been cataloged individually.

scopecontent.p: Charles A. Leale was the first physician to attend President Abraham Lincoln after Lincoln was shot at Ford's Theatre on April 14, 1865. This photograph shows the physician and his family at their home. Included are Dr. Leale, his wife Rebecca Medwin Copcutt Leale, and their children Annie, Lilian, Medwin, Marion, and Loyal.
Four advertisements for photographic studios, a receipt from Brady's gallery, and two printed illustrations relating to daguerreotypes.

This modern praxinoscope is decorated on the top and outside with a circus theme and the designation "hemisferium." The pictures on the strips to be viewed include dancing figures, tumblers, and a toy soldier on a rocking horse.
did.abstract: Invented by Charles-Émile Reynaud in 1877, the praxinoscope was an animation device, the successor to the zoetrope. It used a strip of pictures placed around the inner surface of a spinning cylinder. An inner circle of mirrors was placed so that the reflections of the pictures appeared more or less stationary in position as the wheel turned. The viewer looking in the mirrors would thus see a rapid succession of images, producing the illusion of motion.

scopecontent.p: This series includes boxed CDVs. For the CDV albums that have been cataloged individually see the list at the end of this guide.

arrangement.p: Alphabetical by name and by subject

did.unittitle: Brady, Lincoln, and the Civil War

did.abstract: Photograph viewer in the form of a wooden box covered in velvet, containing two rollers, with a viewing window on the top. By turning one of two knobs on the front of the device, the viewer can move forward or back through a roll of photographs on the two rollers. The roll contains many reproductions of engravings or lithographs in addition to (unidentified) portrait photographs. The images are in carte de visite format, but inserted into a continuous roll of paper photo frames. Images include a photo of a Union army officer from the Civil War.

processinfo.p: Awaiting treatment by Conservation, not yet available.

did.unittitle: Historian George Sullivan's Mathew Brady Research Archive

bioghist.p: Historian George Sullivan, author of Mathew Brady: His Life and Photographs (1994) and In the Wake of Battle: The Civil War Images of Mathew Brady (2004) was one of the foremost authorities on the life and work of Mathew Brady. This collection, organized in three-ring binders and file folders, comprises correspondence, notes, web printouts, photocopies, photographic prints, and tear sheets, represents Sullivan’s lifetime reference archive.

bioghist.p: Seward was Lincoln's Secretary of State

scopecontent.p: The contents of the album have been house separately in the same box.

userestrict.p: Please use care when handling the album as the binding is broken.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Charles A. Leale and family

scopecontent.p: Photograph of physician Charles A. Leale and his family at home. Shown are Dr. Leale, his wife Rebecca Medwin Copcutt Leale, and their children Annie, Lilian, Medwin, Marion, and Loyal. The photographer is Pach Bros. Charles A. Leale was the first physician to attend President Lincoln after Lincoln was shot at Ford's Theatre on April 14, 1865.
